repnme.cdata!:
Peru - Health Reform Program (First Phase:
            Mother and Child Insurance and Decentralization of Health Service)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Reform Program
            (First Phase: Mother and Child Insurance and
            Decentralization of Health Service) in Peru were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Lessons learned included: 1) Political volatility has a
            detrimental effect on Project implementation and impact; 2)
            Use of a variety of lending and non-lending instruments can
            enhance the implementation of critical sectoral reforms; 3)
            Ensuring implementation readiness conditions prior to
            negotiations leads to a more effective and timely physical
            and financial execution cycle; 4) The use of a clear
            evidence-based causality model can strongly enhance the
            achievement of Project Development Objectives; 5)
            Intercultural strategies are vital when beneficiaries belong
            to diverse indigenous groups; 6) Community ownership of
            project activities is likely to contribute to the
            sustainability of a health reform process through
            participatory maintenance of the goods provided and promotes
            decentralization under a context of ensuring accountability
            and equity; and 7) Rehabilitation of health facilities needs
            to pay greater attention to overall utility capacity, in
            order to ensure that new facilities have sufficient
            availability of electricity, water and sanitation services.

5086145.trustfund: TF037587-PERU - HEALTH SECTOR REFORM,TF037585-PERU - HEALTH SECTOR REFORM,TF025368-PHRD-HEALTH SECTOR REFORM PROJECT,TF037584-PERU - HEALTH SECTOR REFORM

abstracts.cdata!:
The medium-term goals of the 10-year
            Health Reform Program Project are to: a) improve maternal
            and child health; and b) help reduce morbidity and deaths of
            the poor from communicable diseases and inadequate
            environmental conditions. Phase I will highlight the
            policies and instruments to improve the access of the poor
            to health-promoting programs and services while preparing
            the analytical work and sensitizing stakeholders to more
            complex systemic reforms. The project components include: 1)
            Strengthening health demand - implementation of Seguro
            Materno Infantil (SMI) which aims to reduce infant and
            maternal mortality by improving access of poor pregnant
            mothers and small children to quality healthcare. The
            program will reimburse health providers for services
            rendered free of charge. 2) Strengthening decentralization,
            policy development, and institutional modernization will
            support expansion of community-managed health facilities
            (CLAS) and empowerment of communities, strengthen the
            capacity of municipalities and regional health boards
            (DISA), support the reorientation of the role of Ministry of
            Health (MINSA) and public/private health providers, and
            support the development of a new unified information system
            for service produciton. 3) Improving the supply and quality
            of health programs and services will finance regional and
            local health plans. 4) A project coordination unit will be
            established to coordinate project implementation.
